repnme.cdata!: Croatia's vulnerable better served and protected

abstracts.cdata!:
This Results Profile talks about how
            Croatia's vulnerable were better served and protected.
            Croatian authorities partnered with the World Bank to
            overhaul the system so it would help welfare beneficiaries
            achieve the greatest self-reliance, and deliver effective
            services to the neediest. World Bank supported Social
            Welfare Development Project, cared for almost 200 children
            with severe physical disabilities. Through the project,
            people with developmental disabilities coped with routine
            tasks like food shopping, cooking, paying bills, opening a
            bank account. Fourteen social welfare centers were built or
            renovated and equipped with a new computer management
            system. Social workers spent less time on administrative
            work and more with their clients. Croatia is a good example
            of a country where changes have been successfully introduced
            nationwide to benefit the neediest and most vulnerable
            members of society.

repnme.cdata!:
Croatia - Social Welfare Development
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Social Welfare
            Development Project for Croatia is to strengthen the quality
            of social services and improve administration, planning and
            policy making of the social welfare system. The extension is
            necessary to provide sufficient time to deliver and install
            the Information Technology (IT) equipment (US$2.1 million)
            and install LAN cabling network (US$0.4 million) in the
            social welfare institutions throughout Croatia. The national
            roll-out of the new social welfare management information
            system is a complex process that requires full
            implementation of three separate IT hardware and software
            contracts and installation of LAN cabling network, as well
            as their functional integration at the national level. Due
            to the delay in the procurement process, implementation of
            one of the IT hardware contracts will require additional
            three months to complete, and given the other contracts for
            supply and installation of hardware and software are
            functionally connected with the hardware procured under the
            contract in question, additional time is required for their
            full integration into one system. This all is expected to be
            achieved by March 31, 2011.

display_title.display_title:
Croatia - Social Welfare
            Development Project : restructuring (Vol. 2) : Data sheet

repnme.cdata!:
Croatia - Social Welfare Development
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Social Welfare
            Development Project for Croatia is to strengthen the quality
            of social services and improve administration, planning and
            policy making of the social welfare system. The extension is
            necessary to provide sufficient time to deliver and install
            the information technology (IT) equipment (US$2.1 million)
            and install LAN (local area network) cabling network (US$0.4
            million) in the social welfare institutions throughout
            Croatia. Without the extension, the Government will not be
            able to use loan funds for completing the two remaining
            activities necessary for the completion of the social
            welfare management information system (MIS). Without Bank
            financing, completion of the mentioned activities will
            depend on ministry of health and social welfare's
            ability to allocate $2.5 million of own funds for this
            purpose, which might be difficult given the reduced
            investment budget of the ministry and could jeopardize the
            completion of the MIS.

repnme.cdata!:
Croatia - Social Welfare Development
            Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Social Welfare
            Development Project for Croatia is to strengthen the quality
            of social services and improve administration, planning and
            policy making of the social welfare system.  The
            restructuring will correct the original mismatch between the
            Project Development Objective (PDO), the Results Framework
            (RF), and the project activities which have been under
            implementation during the last three years. Firstly, the PDO
            makes reference to improved targeting and administrative
            simplicity of social benefits, and there are two
            corresponding outcome indicators, one aiming at 5-10 percent
            increase in all targeted social benefits that reaches the
            bottom quintile of the population, and the other referring
            to improved targeting and administrative simplicity through
            streamlined benefit entitlements in the social welfare act.
            However, the project activities, with the exception of one
            small consultancy, have had no direct impact on achieving
            improved targeting and administrative efficiency of social
            benefits. This objective was intended to be achieved through
            the Second Programmatic Adjustment Loan (PAL II), which had
            one specific condition on improving targeting of social
            benefits, and was not achieved under that operation.
            Secondly, the outcome indicator on annual reduction of
            referrals to resident institutions by 10 percent, starting
            from 2008, is not attributable to the project, as the
            project activities did not foresee any transformation of and
            reduction in the capacity of social welfare residential
            institutions. Also, several intermediate results indicators
            related to inappropriate outcome indicators needed to be
            dropped, revised, and replaced by new indicators to reflect
            the intended project results.
